Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Motivations, Expectations and Goal Pursuit in Social Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will test a conceptual model of the relationship between social media goal pursuit and well-being that is grounded in motivational theory and results from two pilot studies. In the theoretical framework, the broad range of goals people have for using social media is uniquely determined by two broad dimensions that specify the primary focus of the 1) content interaction and the 2) person interaction. The social media goals corresponding to these dimensions are hypothesized to be pursued according to the basic needs that social media satisfy for its users and the motivational orientations supported by those needs. The model states how goals lead to different well-being outcomes with the relationship between social media goal pursuit and well-being moderated by perceptions of overall well-being in specific life domains, along with constructs related to social identity. Three studies will test and validate the conceptual model: validation of the dimensions underlying social media goal pursuit (Study 1), development of new scales to measure the social media goals (Study 2), and testing and refinement of the model in a structural equation modeling framework (Study 3). The model will permit examination of a host of research questions including whether certain social media goals render individuals more vulnerable to negative well-being outcomes. For example, do individuals low in well-being pursue particular social media goals in the hope of improving their lives? Are these goals different from those that individuals more satisfied with their lives pursue? The model will allow researchers to build upon a common set of constructs and can increase understanding of why people use social media, along with its benefits and consequences.

A validated theoretical framework relating higher-order social media goals to subjective well-being in the context of basic needs and motivations has the potential to advance foundational research in multiple domains of inquiry. Consumer psychologists and marketing academics can use the framework to examine the relationship between social media goals and consumer response to marketing efforts in interactive media environments. Social psychologists and personality researchers can further refine and extend the framework to include other important constructs likely to impact social media goal pursuit and well-being. Computer information systems researchers can use the model to further understand how social media systems are impacted by individual differences. Although there has been a great deal of descriptive research examining the different usage behaviors people engage in when they use social media, most studies tend to focus narrowly on reasons or motivations for using a particular type of social media, rather than on organizing the results in the context of a broader conceptual framework that can explain what drives use and how usage goals are related to key well-being outcomes. Understanding the drivers of social media use and its consequences for well-being will have important national policy and consumer welfare implications.

Social media holds great potential for meeting user’s fundamental needs to connect with others and previous literature has provided many valuable insights about various aspects of consumers’ feelings of connection with others from social media usage. Yet despite the fact that social media offers users opportunities to connect with each other in a variety of ways, little work has focused on how what consumers do on social media interacts with why they do it to impact their feelings of connection with others. Further, to the extent that these interactions, when engaged in during brand contexts, are likely to transfer to feelings of brand connection, these relationships could have important implications for brands’ social media marketing efforts. 

In this project, we tested the circumstances under which users are more likely to feel connected with others when they are engaging in direct interaction versus indirection interaction. We theorized that a user’s underlying motivational orientation to engage in a particular social media interaction strategy would moderate their feelings of connectedness when using social media. We differentiated between two important motivations for using social media: using it because it is ideally what one wants to do, and using it because one feels they ought to, out of a sense of duty or obligation. We proposed that direct interactions should match best with a wants-to focus, and indirect interactions should yield fit with an ought-to focus. Both these fit strategies produce feelings of connectedness from a “feels-right” sensation. As far as we are aware, this was the first project to examine the effects of social media use as the outcome of the interaction between the behaviors people adopt in social media and the motivation underlying the behaviors.

We employed an extensive set of measurement and multilevel modeling procedures to refine and test the theoretical framework that argued that peoples’ feelings of connection with others on social media arises from the interaction between what they do on social media (social media behavior strategies) and why they do it (motivational orientation). Then, we validated this framework empirically by conducting an extensive set of controlled experiments across a variety of social media contexts. We also established the boundary conditions of the observed effects and demonstrated that the results also obtain in a variety brand-related social media interactions with important downstream consequences for brands’ marketing efforts.

Correlational and experimental results from six studies supported our dual and contrasting predictions about how users may feel closer to others in social media and the brand-related implications of those experiences of connection. Users’ feelings of connection to their social media “friends” depends on the type of interaction strategy they employ in combination with their motivational orientation to engage in the behavior. Specifically, when using a direct strategy compared to an indirect strategy, users feel more connected to their Facebook friends when they ideally want to use social media. When users feel that they ought to use social media, however, this effect reverses: indirect strategies are more likely than direct strategies to lead to stronger feelings of connection in Facebook.
